experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. I'll be honest—I'm pretty nervous about this, but I know I need to get better at, like, just talking to people without feeling like I'm going to say the wrong thing.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! First off, major props for stepping out of your comfort zone—that’s already a huge win. Since you’re low in social anxiety, lean into that strength! Start small: practice speaking up in smaller study groups before tackling large lectures. Join a club like Toastmasters or a CS group where you can present projects—it’s low-pressure and builds confidence. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I do okay in my study group, but the thought of presenting my project to the whole CS club just makes my stomach turn. What if my code isn't good enough?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to feel that way! Remember, everyone in the CS club was once a beginner too. Focus on sharing what you've learned, not perfection. Start by presenting to just one or two club members first—it's less intimidating and still builds experience. You belong there just as much as anyone else!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I guess you're right. It's just hard to remember that when it feels like everyone else is already an expert. Maybe I could ask Ben and Sarah to listen first, they're usually pretty nice about stuff.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a perfect plan! Ben and Sarah sound like great practice allies. Their feedback will help you refine your presentation and boost your confidence. Remember, even "experts" started somewhere—you're on the right track by taking these small, brave steps. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I guess. I'm just worried they'll think my topic is too basic for grad school applications. But I'll try to see it as a practice run.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly—think of it as a low-stakes practice run! Grad schools value clarity and communication skills just as much as complex topics. Presenting a "basic" topic well shows you can explain concepts effectively, which is a huge strength. You’ve got this, Gregory!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense... I just worry they'll think my topic isn't sophisticated enough for grad-level work. But maybe you're right about the clarity part.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Definitely! Clear communication is a superpower in academia and tech. Even advanced research needs to be explained accessibly. If you can make a "basic" topic engaging and easy to grasp, that’s a skill grad programs actively look for. Trust your preparation—you’re building exactly the right foundation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess that makes sense, it's just hard to believe my presentation on basic data structures is actually valuable. I keep worrying the professors are looking for something more complex.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Remember, even professors appreciate a well-explained foundational topic—it shows you truly understand the building blocks of CS. Many students overcomplicate things; your clarity could actually stand out! Plus, this is practice for tailoring explanations to any audience, a key skill for grad school interviews and TA positions. You're building a solid foundation.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I just worry that explaining basic concepts might make me seem like I'm not advanced enough for grad school. But you're right, maybe keeping it simple would actually help with my TA application.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Think of it this way: if you can teach a basic concept clearly, you prove you deeply understand it—that's what makes a great TA and researcher. Grad schools want candidates who can communicate complex ideas simply. You're not just presenting; you're demonstrating a crucial skill. Keep focusing on clarity—it's your strength!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually makes a lot of sense. I guess I just get so worried about sounding smart that I forget making it clear is the whole point.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! Clarity *is* intelligence. The best researchers and engineers are the ones who can make complex ideas accessible. You're already thinking like an educator—that's a huge asset for grad school and beyond. Keep trusting that approach!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that means a lot. I just worry sometimes that simplifying things might make my work seem less serious to admissions committees.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Not at all—admissions committees see hundreds of overly complex statements. A clear, well-explained project shows confidence and mastery. Think of it like clean code: elegant and effective. You're demonstrating you understand the "why," not just the "how," which is exactly what they're looking for.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually makes a lot of sense. I guess I just worry that my project isn't impressive enough compared to what other applicants might have done.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Comparison is the thief of joy! Grad schools look for passion and depth, not just flashy projects. Your genuine interest and ability to explain your work clearly will stand out far more than a project you did just to pad your resume. Own your journey—it's uniquely yours.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I know you're right... it's just hard not to compare when everyone in my study group seems to have these perfect, complex project portfolios. I guess I just worry my work isn't impressive enough on paper.

improvement_areas: Improve i stay calm when dealing with problems.

responses.question: I stay calm when dealing with problems.

responses.question: I help my friends when they are having a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 3. [Rating: 4/4] Absolutely. If a friend is struggling with a coding problem or just having a rough day, I'm the first one to offer help or just listen. It's easier to focus on others' problems than m...

responses.question: I work well with my classmates.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 4. [Rating: 4/4] Group projects are usually fine. I like collaborating and brainstorming solutions. As long as everyone does their part, I find it more engaging than working alone....

responses.question: I do the right thing without being told.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 5. [Rating: 3/4] I try to, especially with academic integrity. But I'll admit I sometimes need a push for non-academic responsibilities, like sorting out my budget for the month....

responses.question: I do my part in a group.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 6. [Rating: 4/4] I'm hyper-aware of not being the person who slacks off in a group. I always make sure my section of the work is done on time and to the best of my ability....

responses.question: I stay calm when I disagree with others.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 7. [Rating: 2/4] This is tough. I'm open to different ideas, but if I'm passionate about something, I can get a bit intense and my tone might get defensive. I'm working on it....

responses.question: I stand up for others when they are not treated well.

responses.question: I am careful when I use things that aren't mine.

responses.question: I let people know when there's a problem.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 11. [Rating: 3/4] It depends on the problem. A bug in a group project? I'll speak up immediately. A personal issue? I'm more likely to keep it to myself until it becomes unavoidable....

responses.question: I pay attention when the teacher talks to the class.
responses.notes: Self-assessment: 12. [Rating: 3/4] Mostly, yes. Unless I'm stressed about something else, like my loans, and my mind wanders. But I'm usually pretty engaged in my CS classes....

responses.notes: Self-assessment: 13. [Rating: 3/4] I try to be encouraging and a good listener. I'm not always the best with emotional...

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thank you for meeting with me. I'm a little nervous, but I really need some help with... well, talking to people, especially if it's for my career.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Jamie! It's totally normal to feel nervous about networking—many students do. Start small: practice introducing yourself to one person in a virtual class or club. Prepare a brief "elevator pitch" about your interests in computer science. Remember, most people are happy to chat if you approach them politely. You've got this—every conversation is a step toward building that network!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I can prepare the elevator pitch, but what if I message someone and they don't reply? That silence feels worse than not trying at all.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a really common fear! Remember, non-replies usually have nothing to do with you—people are busy or might miss messages. Try not to take it personally. Maybe set a goal like "I'll message three people this week" rather than focusing on responses. Each attempt builds courage, and you'll feel more confident with practice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that. I just worry that if no one replies, it means my message was awkward or they don't want to talk to me.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's natural to overanalyze, but silence usually means they're swamped or your message got buried—not that you're awkward! Try framing messages with a clear, low-pressure question like "I admired your project on X—would you be open to sharing how you got started?" This makes responding easy. You're being brave by reaching out—that itself is a win!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That does sound less intimidating. I'm just worried my admiration will come across as insincere, since I'm not great at small talk. But I'll try drafting a message like that.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Being specific helps sincerity shine through! Instead of "great project," try "Your use of machine learning in your climate app was impressive—especially how you handled data preprocessing." Authentic details show genuine interest. You're not just making small talk; you're starting a meaningful connection. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That makes sense. It just feels like I need to know so much about their project beforehand to say something that specific. What if I get a detail wrong?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a thoughtful concern, but getting a detail slightly wrong can actually be a great conversation starter! It shows you made an effort and gives them an opportunity to kindly correct you, which can feel more like a collaborative chat than an interview. Aim for "I think you used X technique—I found that fascinating!" instead of stating it as absolute fact. Your willingness to learn is what matters most.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: But if I get it wrong, they'll think I wasn't paying attention or that I'm not competent. I just want to be accurate.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's totally understandable to worry about that! But remember, professionals appreciate curiosity more than perfection. If you're off on a detail, it often opens the door for them to explain—which builds rapport. Think of it as showing you're engaged and eager to learn, not as a test of your expertise. Your conscientiousness is a strength, but it's okay to let it guide rather than paralyze you. You're reaching out to grow, not to prove you already know everything.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but the idea of saying something incorrect to a professional just makes my mind go blank. What if they think I'm not prepared?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That "blank mind" feeling is so real with social anxiety. Let's simplify: you don't need to be an expert on their work. Try a question instead, like, "I was really impressed by your project—could you tell me what inspired the approach you took?" This shifts the pressure to them, shows interest, and avoids the risk of misspeaking. You're not expected to have all the answers; you're there to learn. Deep breath—you can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good question. I'm just worried my mind will go blank again and I'll forget to ask it. What if I stumble over the words?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great question. It's completely normal to worry about stumbling—most people do! Try writing 2-3 simple, open-ended questions on a small notecard or in your phone notes before the conversation. You can glance at it if you freeze. Something like, "What do you enjoy most about your work?" is easy to remember and starts a positive dialogue. It’s not about perfect delivery; it’s about making a genuine connection. You’ve got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's... actually a really practical idea. I'll write those down right now so I don't forget. I just hope my mind doesn't go completely blank anyway.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great first step! If your mind still goes blank, it's okay to pause and say, "I'm just collecting my thoughts—I really admire your work." That honesty actually builds connection. Professionals have been there too. You're preparing thoughtfully, which already puts you ahead. Keep those notes handy and trust yourself—you're more capable than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay. I'll try that phrase. I just worry that even with notes, my mind will freeze and they'll think I'm not competent.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: It's totally valid to worry about that. Remember, freezing doesn't mean you're incompetent—it means you're human. Most people are more focused on their own responses than judging you. If you freeze, a simple, "Sorry, I'm a bit nervous—I really admire your work" is honest and relatable. People respect authenticity more than perfect performance. You're taking brave steps, and that's what matters most.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good line to remember. I just worry that in the moment, my mind will go completely blank and I won't be able to say anything at all.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I’m Alex. I guess I’m here because I know I need to get better at… well, the social parts of college, especially if I want to land a good internship.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 10/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 4/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 3/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 2/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Campus social events
- Social comfort: 3/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Art History
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Homesickness
- Goals: Land a dream internship, Start a student organization, Graduate with honors, Improve time management
- Challenges: Balancing extracurricular activities with studies, Building time management, Financial planning, Developing effective study habits
- Behaviors: Uses campus resources like tutoring, Seeks out leadership roles, Studies in the library regularly

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hi Alex! It's great that you're being proactive about building connections. Since you're low in social anxiety, lean into that strength—start small by attending department events or joining a club related to art history. These are natural ways to meet people with similar interests. Also, connect with professors during office hours; they often have internship leads. You've got this—your conscientiousness will help you follow through!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's a good point about professors having internship leads. I'll check the department calendar for events this week, though I'm worried about balancing that with my student organization work.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Great plan! Try blocking out specific times for your organization and studies in a planner—this helps prevent overcommitment. Also, look for overlap: could your organization host an event that connects to art history? That way you’re building networks while managing your time efficiently. You’re already on the right track!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's actually a really helpful idea—combining the organization work with my major would take some pressure off. I'll try the planner system, though I'm a bit worried about sticking to a rigid schedule.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally understandable—rigid schedules can feel restrictive. Try using your planner flexibly: block out must-do tasks (like classes/studying) but leave open slots for spontaneity. The goal is to reduce stress, not add to it. You're being thoughtful about this, which is half the battle!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds less overwhelming than my current system. I'm just worried if I leave things too open, I'll fall behind on my senior thesis research.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Break your thesis into small, manageable steps (like "find 3 sources" or "write 500 words") and schedule just one per day. That way, you make steady progress without feeling trapped. You’ve been conscientious so far—trust that momentum!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That actually sounds... manageable. I'll try starting with the sources tomorrow morning at the library.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! Starting small and in a focused space like the library sets you up for success. You’ve got this—one step at a time is how big projects get done. Proud of you for taking action!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that means a lot. I just hope I can keep this momentum going when the big research paper is due.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: You will! Momentum builds with consistency, not perfection. Even 30 minutes of focused work daily adds up. Celebrate small wins—you're building habits that will last beyond this paper. Keep going!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: You're right. I'll try to focus on just getting that half-hour in today. It's just hard not to feel overwhelmed by the whole project at once.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Totally normal to feel that way! Try setting a timer for 30 minutes and then giving yourself permission to stop. Often, starting is the hardest part—once you begin, you might even want to keep going. You're doing great by breaking it down!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's actually really practical advice—I'll try it with my art history readings tonight. Thank you for saying I'm doing great; that helps more than you know.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Of course—you deserve to hear it! Tackling readings in small, timed chunks is a smart move. Remember, progress over perfection. You're building skills that will help in your internship search too. Keep trusting the process

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that means a lot. I just worry that even with good study habits, my resume won't stand out against other art history majors.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Your student organization idea is a huge differentiator! Combine that with your developing study skills, and you're building a unique profile. Internships love candidates with initiative—you're already on the right track.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thank you. I just worry that the organization won't seem impressive enough compared to what other students are doing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Your passion is what will make it impressive! Start small—even a dedicated study group can grow into something bigger. Authentic projects always stand out more than generic ones. You've got this

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's true—I've been thinking about starting an Art History study group. I'm just worried about finding the right people who are as dedicated.
